Hi Jim,
just thinking about these numbers which at first sight seem stagger=
ing. However when you view it in context the prices paid for works by top e=
nd masters is still comparatively modest. Going back to the Rai Kunimitsu b=
ought in 2001. $320k would buy a reasonable/modest house in London. But com=
pare that to what you would have to pay for a top work by a 20th. century p=
ainter, Luceun Freud currently commands in excess of $1.5million for each n=
ew painting. In what other field could collectors still buy works by the wo=
rlds leading exponents of their craft throughout history at these prices.
W=
hat this means for the rest of us mortals is that very high quality work by=
 recognised masters can still be obtained affordably, not necessarily easil=
y, but within the realms of possibility. I cant think of another field of a=
rt where this is the case.

Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:
Hi=
 Paul,
A lot of the highest level items tend to change hands privately in J=
apan.  I don't know the answer to Matt's question, but the highest tsuba pr=
ice I personally have heard was ~US$350k.  No doubt there are higher prices=
 that I have not heard...
Jim


  I think the highest auction price paid fo=
r a sword is still the Kiyomaru bought from the Francis Festing collection =
auction in 1993. That sold for about $450k to a japanese dealer (I think AO=
I-Art). So assume it sold retail for a lot more. Other close contenders wou=
ld include some of the blades sold in the Manno collection sale in 2001wher=
e a Rai Kunimitsu made approx $320k.

  "Matthew E. Hoyle" <matthewhoyle@wa=
nadoo.nl> wrote:Anybody know what the world record prices are for 1. a tsub=
a, 2. a
  sword, 3 a koshirae etc ?

  Matt
